title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Abstract. This research project investigates the dynamic effects of the U.S. Dollar (USD) on the Australian economy, with a focus on economic stability. By employing Bayesian Structural Vector Autoregression (SVAR) analysis. This study aims to elucidate the transmission mechanisms of USD fluctuations through three channels: GDP growth, inflation, and unemployment. The findings are expected to provide nuanced insights into the macroeconomic interdependencies between the USD and the Australian economy, offering valuable perspectives for policymakers and economic analysts.
Keywords. Bayesian SVAR, USD, Australian economy, inflation, economic stability

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Likelihood
The likelihood function for the model is:
\[
p(Y \mid B_0, B_p, \lambda, X) = (2\pi\lambda)^{-\frac{T}{2}} \exp\left(-\frac{1}{2\lambda} \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) \right)
\]

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Prior for \(\lambda\)
The Inverted-Gamma 2 prior for () is:
\[
p(\lambda) = \frac{(\underline{s}/2)^{\underline{\nu}/2}}{\Gamma(\underline{\nu}/2)} \lambda^{-\underline{\nu}/2-1} \exp\left(-\frac{\underline{s}}{2\lambda}\right)
\]

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Prior for \(B_0\) and \(B_p\)
The Normal-Gamma-Normal (NGN) prior for (B_0) and (B_p) is assumed to be:
\[
p(B_0, B_p) \propto \left| \det(B_0) \right|^{\underline{\nu}} \exp \left( -\frac{1}{2} \left[ \operatorname{tr}((B_0 - \underline{B}) \underline{\Omega}^{-1} (B_0 - \underline{B})^T) \right] \right)
\]

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Posterior Derivation
The posterior distribution is proportional to the product of the likelihood and the priors:
\[
p(B_0, B_p, \lambda \mid Y, X) \propto p(Y \mid B_0, B_p, \lambda, X) p(B_0, B_p) p(\lambda)
\]

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Posterior for \(\lambda\)
Combining the likelihood and the prior for ():
\[
p(\lambda \mid Y, B_0, B_p, X) \propto \lambda^{-\frac{T}{2}} \exp\left(-\frac{1}{2\lambda} \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) \right) \lambda^{-\underline{\nu}/2-1} \exp\left(-\frac{\underline{s}}{2\lambda}\right)
\]
Combining terms:
\[
p(\lambda \mid Y, B_0, B_p, X) \propto \lambda^{-\left(\frac{T}{2} + \frac{\underline{\nu}}{2} + 1\right)} \exp\left(-\frac{1}{2\lambda} \left(\sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) + \underline{s}\right)\right)
\]
This is recognized as the kernel of an Inverted-Gamma 2 distribution:
\[
\lambda \mid Y, B_0, B_p, X \sim \mathcal{IG2}\left(\underline{s} + \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) , \underline{\nu} + T \right)
\]
We use the results from the basic model (above) to compute the error terms that will be used in sampling \(\lambda\).

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Posterior for \(B_0\) and \(B_p\)
Considering the effect of \(\lambda\) on the residuals, the posterior parameters for \(B_0\) and \(B_p\) should be adjusted accordingly. The presence of \(\lambda\) affects the variance in the likelihood, impacting the posterior distributions for \(B_0\) and \(B_p\).

Update Posterior Parameters
Taking \(\lambda\) into account, the posterior parameters for \(B_0\) and \(B_p\) are:

Posterior for \(\bar{\Omega}\):

\[
\bar{\Omega} = \left(\frac{XX^T}{\lambda} + \underline{\Omega}^{-1}\right)^{-1}
\]

Posterior for \(\bar{B}\):

\[
\bar{B} = \left(\frac{XX^T}{\lambda} + \underline{\Omega}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \left(\frac{YX^T}{\lambda} + \underline{\Omega}^{-1}\underline{B}\right)
\]

Posterior for \(\bar{S}\):

\[
\bar{S} = \left( \frac{YY^T}{\lambda} + \underline{S}^{-1} + \underline{B}^{-1}\underline{B}^T - \bar{B}\bar{\Omega}\bar{B}^T \right)
\]

Posterior for \(\bar{\nu}\):

\[
\bar{\nu} = T + \underline{\nu}
\]

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Conclusion
We have re-derived the posteriors for the modified Bayesian SVAR model with the correct Inverted-Gamma 2 prior for \(\lambda\), where \(\lambda \sim \mathcal{IG2}(\underline{s}, \underline{\nu})\) with \(\underline{s} = \underline{\nu} - 2\). The correct derivation shows that \(\lambda\) scales the variance in the likelihood, impacting the posterior distributions of \(B_0\) and \(B_p\).
This approach highlights the importance of correctly handling matrix operations and applying Bayesian inference principles to a more complex model structure.

Second Extension: Estimating \(\nu\)
Following Lee (2022) we use a Metropolis-Hastings Algorithm to estimate \(\nu\) and impose a vmode value corresponding to the t-distribution range \((0, 25)\).


Conclusion
The overall kernel for this extended model encapsulates to the random variance \(\lambda\). This allows for a more robust handling of heteroscedasticity and potential non-stationarities in the error terms, offering nuanced insights into the dynamics under study.
In the basic model, all USD Index contemporaneous coefficients are not statistically significant at the standard levels. On the other hand, all these coefficients in the extended model are statistically significant at the 5% level.
The results suggest the following elasticities. According to the basic model, a weaker Dixie is likely to overheat the Australian economy: a drop of 1 per cent in the USD Index would result in roughly 1 per cent increase in inflation, roughly unchanged unemployment, and roughly 1% increase in the GDP growth rate.
On the other hand, the expanded model suggests that a weakening Dixie would result in an untraditional condition in the Australian economy: 1 per cent decrease in the USD Index would result is roughly 0.7 per cent increase in inflation, roughly 1 per cent increase in unemployment, and roughly 1 per cent increase in the GDP growth rate.
As to the second extension, where \(\nu\) is a hyperparameter, this model suggests that a weakening Dixie would result in stagflation in Australia: 1 per cent decrease in the USD Index would result is roughly 3 per cent increase in inflation, roughly 0.7 per cent increase in unemployment, and roughly 3 per cent decrease in the GDP growth rate.

rgn_for_Extension_I_model = function(n,V,B0.initial){

   y   = Y
  
  # Basic settings and model dimensions
  N <- ncol(y)
  p <- 12   # This is the number of lags in the model
  K <- 1 + N * p

  # Set the priors
  kappa1 <- 0.01      # autoregressive slope shrinkage
  kappa2 <- 1         # constant term shrinkage 
  kappa3 <- 100       # contemporaneous effects shrinkage
  kappa4 <- 1         # VAR prior persistence
   

# create Y and X
############################################################
Y       = y[(p+1):nrow(y),]
X       = matrix(1,nrow(Y),1)
for (i in 1:p){
  X     = cbind(X,y[((p+1):nrow(y))-i,])
}

Y       = t(Y)
X       = t(X)
  
 
  priors <- list(
    B = cbind(rep(0, N), kappa4 * diag(N), matrix(0, N, (p - 1) * N)),
    Omega = diag(c(kappa2, kappa1 * ((1:p)^(-2)) %x% rep(1, N))),
    S = kappa3 * diag(N),
    nu = N
  )
  
   beta  = 5
  total = 0 
 
    A <- Y[ ,i]
    A <- matrix(A, ncol = 1)
    B <- X[ , i]
    B <- matrix(B, ncol = 1)
    C <- (B0_posterior1[ , , S]%*%A - Bp_posterior1[ , ,S]%*%B)
 
    partial_sum = t(C)%*%C
    total = total + partial_sum
  
  
  alpha = (beta - 2) + total
  
  N             = nrow(B0.initial)
  no.draws      = n
  
  B0            = array(NA, c(N,N,no.draws))
  B0.aux        = B0.initial
  
  for (i in 1:no.draws){
    
        # Sample lambda from the Inverse Gamma distribution

  lambda <- rinvgamma(n = 1, shape = alpha, rate = beta + nrow(y))
  
  lambda_posterior <- lambda

    # Compute posterior distribution parameters
  Omega.inv <- solve(priors$Omega)
  Omega.post.inv <-  ((lambda_posterior)^(-1) * X %*% t(X) +  Omega.inv)
  Omega.post <- solve(Omega.post.inv)
  B.post <-   ( (lambda_posterior)^(-1) * Y %*% t(X) +  priors$B %*% Omega.inv) %*% Omega.post
  S.post <-  solve( (lambda_posterior)^(-1) * Y %*% t(Y) +  solve(priors$S) + priors$B %*% Omega.inv %*% t(priors$B) - B.post %*% Omega.post.inv %*% t(B.post))
  nu.post <- nrow(y) + priors$nu
  
  posteriors <- list(
    B = B.post,
    Omega = Omega.post,
    S = S.post,
    nu = nu.post
  )

  S.inv = solve(S.post)
    
    for (n in 1:N){
      rn            = nrow(V[[n]])
      Un            = chol(nu*solve(V[[n]]%*%S.inv%*%t(V[[n]])))
      w             = t(orthogonal.complement.matrix.TW(t(B0.aux[-n,])))
      w1            = w %*% t(V[[n]]) %*% t(Un) / sqrt(as.numeric(w %*% t(V[[n]]) %*% t(Un) %*% Un %*% V[[n]] %*% t(w)))
      if (rn>1){
        Wn          = cbind(t(w1),orthogonal.complement.matrix.TW(t(w1)))
      } else {
        Wn          = w1
      }
      alpha         = rep(NA,rn)
      u             = rmvnorm(1,rep(0,nu+1),(1/nu)*diag(nu+1))
      alpha[1]      = sqrt(as.numeric(u%*%t(u)))
      if (runif(1)<0.5){
        alpha[1]    = -alpha[1]
      }
      if (rn>1){
        alpha[2:rn] = rmvnorm(1,rep(0,nrow(V[[n]])-1),(1/nu)*diag(rn-1))
      }
      bn            = alpha %*% Wn %*% Un
      B0.aux[n,]    = bn %*% V[[n]]
    }
    B0[,,i]         = B0.aux
  }
  
  return(B0)
}

text:
Marginal Likelihood
First, we derive the marginal likelihood by integrating out \(\lambda\): \[
p(Y \mid B_0, B_p, X) = \int p(Y \mid B_0, B_p, \lambda, X) p(\lambda) \, d\lambda
\]
The likelihood and the prior for \(\lambda\) combine as: \[
p(Y \mid B_0, B_p, \lambda, X) p(\lambda) \propto \lambda^{-\left( \frac{T}{2} + \frac{\alpha}{2} + 1 \right)} \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2\lambda} \left( \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) + \beta \right) \right)
\]
Performing the integral: \[
\int_0^\infty \lambda^{-\left( \frac{T}{2} + \frac{\alpha}{2} + 1 \right)} \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2\lambda} \left( \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) + \beta \right) \right) d\lambda
\]
This integral is a standard form for the Inverted-Gamma distribution, yielding the marginal likelihood: \[
p(Y \mid B_0, B_p, X) \propto \left( \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) + \beta \right)^{-\left( \frac{T}{2} + \frac{\alpha}{2} \right)}
\]

Recognize the combined quadratic form: \[
-\frac{1}{2} \left( (B_0 Y - B_p X)^T B_0^T B_0 (B_0 Y - B_p X) + (B_0 - \underline{B}) \underline{\Omega}^{-1} (B_0 - \underline{B}) \right)

text:
Model Extensions
The explanation of the the baseline model and the three extension provided in this report is as follows:







Model
Description




Baseline Model
Lambda is a constant equal to one.


Extension I
Lambda is IG2 (s, nu) and s is estimated from the posterior distribution, while nu is taken as a constant.


Extension II
Lambda is IG2 (s, nu) and s taken as a constant, while nu is sampled from the data.


Extension III
Both s and nu are integrated from the previous two extensions, with Lambda IG2 (s, nu).









Where \(\lambda\) is the variance of the error terms in the model, namely, \(U_t ~ \mathcal{N}(0_T, \lambda I_T)\).

Explanation:

Baseline Model:

\(\lambda\) is a constant equal to one.

Extension I:

Lambda is ~ \(\mathcal{IG2}\) (s, nu)
s is estimated from the posterior distribution.
nu is taken as a constant.

Extension II:

Lambda is ~ \(\mathcal{IG2}\) (s, nu)
s is taken as a constant.
nu is sampled from the data.

Extension III:

Both s and nu are integrated from the previous two extensions.
Lambda is ~ \(\mathcal{IG2}\) (s, nu).




Model Extension I: Solving the Identification Problem Using a Non-Normality Approach
We present the Bayesian estimation and inference methodology for an N-variate Student-t distribution modeled as an IG2-scale mixture of normals. The derivation of the full conditional posterior distributions is expanded step-by-step, and the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm is used for sampling the degrees of freedom parameter \(\nu\). An R function implementing the sampler is provided.
The Student-t distribution is commonly used in statistical modeling to handle data with heavier tails than the normal distribution. An essential parameter of the Student-t distribution is the degrees of freedom \(\nu\), which controls the tail heaviness. In this note, we present the Bayesian estimation of the degrees of freedom parameter for an N-variate Student-t distribution using the Inverted-Gamma 2 (IG2) scale mixture of normals.
The N-variate Student-t distribution can be represented as a scale mixture of normals:

Model Setup
The model is given by: \[
B_0 Y = B_p X + U_t, \quad U_t \sim \mathcal{N}(0_T, \lambda I_T)
\]
The priors are: \[
p(B_0, B_p) \sim \mathcal{NGN}(\underline{B}, \underline{\Omega}, \underline{S}, \underline{\nu})
\] \[
\lambda \sim \mathcal{IG2}(\underline{s}, \underline{\nu})
\]
Where \(\underline{s} = \underline{\nu} - 2\) to ensure that the mean is eaual to one, as was the case under the basic model.


Likelihood Function
The likelihood function for the model is: \[
p(Y \mid B_0, B_p, \lambda, X) = (2\pi\lambda)^{-\frac{T}{2}} \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2\lambda} \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) \right)
\]


Prior for \(\lambda\)
The Inverted-Gamma 2 prior for \(\lambda\) is: \[
p(\lambda) = \frac{(s/2)^{\nu/2}}{\Gamma(\nu/2)} \lambda^{-\nu/2-1} \exp\left( -\frac{s}{2\lambda} \right)
\]


Posterior for \(\lambda\)
Combining the likelihood and the prior for \(\lambda\), we get: \[
p(\lambda \mid Y, B_0, B_p, X) \propto \lambda^{-\left( \frac{T}{2} + \frac{\nu}{2} + 1 \right)} \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2\lambda} \left( \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) + s \right) \right)
\]
This is the kernel of an Inverted-Gamma 2 distribution: \[
\lambda \mid Y, B_0, B_p, X \sim \mathcal{IG2}\left( \nu + T, \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) + s \right)
\]
The posterior mean of \(\lambda\) is: \[
\hat{\lambda} = \frac{s + \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)}{\nu + T - 2}
\]


Combining with the Prior
Assuming the prior \(p(B^+; B_0)\) as given or formulated according to specific assumptions (such as independence, Gaussian priors for coefficients, etc.), the full posterior kernel combining this likelihood with the prior can be approached as:
\[
p(B_+; B_0 \mid Y; X) \propto p(Y \mid X, B_+, B_0) \times p(B_+; B_0)
\]
This expression must often be evaluated or sampled using computational Bayesian techniques, such as Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC), especially given the integrative step required for \(\lambda\).
The resulting poserior distribution is also a Normal-Generalized-Normal distribution.
We can obtain the following posterior formulas similar to the basic model. Note that we use \(\underline{\Omega} = \underline{\lambda\Omega}\) in the following equations:
\[
\bar{\Omega} = [XX^T+ \underline{{\Omega}} \ ]^{-1}
\]
\[
\bar{B} = [YX^T+\underline{B{\Omega}}^{-1}]\bar{\Omega}
\]
\[
\bar{S} = [YY^T+\underline{S}^{-1}+ \underline{B{\Omega}}^{-1} \underline{B}^T - \overline{B{\Omega}}^{-1} \bar{B}]^{-1}
\]
Where
\[
\underline{S} = ( s * I_N + \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t))
\]
We introduce the posterior scale for \(\lambda\) indirectly, through the kappa3 parameter of the Minnesota prior.


Posterior for \(\bar{\nu}\)
\[
\bar{\nu} = T + \underline{\nu}
\]
Where \(\underline{\nu} = \underline {s} + 2 = 5 + 2 = 7\).
The Extension I model is similar to the reduced form model that can be described as (from lecture 8):
\[
Y = XA + E
\]
Where:

\(E|X \sim MN_{T \times N}(0_{T \times N}, \Sigma, I_T)\)
\(A\) is a \(K \times N\) matrix that is said to follow a matrix-variate normal distribution:

\[
A \sim MN_{K \times N}(M, Q, P)
\]
Here:

\(M\) is a \(K \times N\) matrix
\(Q\) is a \(N \times N\) row-specific covariance matrix
\(P\) is a \(K \times K\) column-specific covariance matrix

An \(N \times N\) square symmetric and positive definite matrix \(\Sigma\) follows an inverse Wishart distribution:
\[
\Sigma \sim IW_N(S, \nu)
\]
Where:

\(S\) is the scale matrix
\(\nu\) is the degrees of freedom

The key point is that for our model, \(\Sigma = \lambda I_N\). This means that \(\lambda\) does not appear directly in the posteriors of our model. Instead, it enters through the priors and posteriors for \(S\) and \(\nu\) of the \(\mathcal{NGN}\) distribution.


Conclusion
The parameters \(s\) and \(\nu\) from the prior distribution of \(\lambda\) affect the posterior distributions for \(B_0\) and \(B_p\) through the variance scaling in the likelihood, influencing \(\bar{S}\). This approach correctly shows that \(\lambda\) does not explicitly appear in the posterior formulas for \(\bar{\Omega}\) and \(\bar{B}\), but \(\lambda\) impacts the overall posterior distribution implicitly. This rigorous derivation demonstrates the correct Bayesian inference for a hierarchical model, incorporating the effects of \(\lambda\) through its posterior distribution.

Conclusion
The overall kernel for this extended model (Extensions I, II, and III) encapsulates the random variance of \(\lambda\). This allows for a more robust handling of heteroscedasticity and potential non-stationarities in the error terms, offering nuanced insights into the dynamics under study.
In the basic model, all USD Index contemporaneous coefficients are not statistically significant at the standard levels. On the other hand, In the Extension I model, the simultaneous effect of the Dixie on GDP growth is statistically significant at the 5% significance level. For the Extension II model, the significant effect is the Dixie simultaneous effect on the unemployment rate, also at the 5% level, plus the simultanous effect of the Dixie on the unemployment rate, which is significant at the 1% level. Extension III produces both significant effects at the same time, and both at the 5% level.
Extensions I, II, and III models all tell the same story. A weaker USD Index is likely to result in stagflation in Australia. A drop in the Dixie will result in an increase in inflation and unemployment, and a drop in the GDP growth rate. However, the IRF plots suggest that the inflation is likely to drop again with in six to seven months, while the unemployment rate is likely to drop within the first four months. The dangeous sign, however, is that the drop in GDP growth rate will not result in any positive rebound in the first 30 months after the shock. At best, the GDP gowth rate will return to its previous level before the drop in teh Dixie.
In particular, the results suggest the following elasticities (see the table below). According to the basic model, a drop of 1 per cent in the USD Index would result in roughly 1 per cent decrease in inflation, roughly 14 per cent unemployment, and roughly 1% decrease in the GDP growth rate.
On the other hand, the first version of the expanded model, namely Extension I, which accounts for a random posterior scale for \(\lambda = \mathcal{IG2(s, \nu)}\), suggests that a weakening Dixie would result in \(\textbf{stagnation}\) in Australia: 1 per cent decrease in the USD Index would result is roughly 23 per cent increase in inflation, roughly 3 per cent increase in unemployment, and roughly 0.2 per cent decrease in the GDP growth rate.
In the second extension model, the Extension II version, \(\lambda\)’s scale is held constant, while the shape parameter for \(\lambda = \mathcal{IG2(s, \nu)}\), namely \(\nu\), is estimated from the data itself, from matrix \(Y\). Here, the model calibrates the \(\textbf{stagnation}\) story told in Extension I. It suggests that a 1 per cent decrease in the USD Index would result is roughly 0.8 per cent increase in inflation, roughly 1.1 per cent increase in unemployment, and roughly 0.6 per cent decrease in the GDP growth rate.
In the third extension model, the Extension III version, \(\lambda\)’s scale and shape are both estimated. The scale is estimated from the posterior for \(\lambda\), while the shape parameter for \(\lambda = \mathcal{IG2(s, \nu)}\), namely \(\nu\), is estimated from the data itself, from matrix \(Y\). Here, the model calibrates the \(\textbf{stagnation}\) story told in Extension II. It suggests that a 1 per cent decrease in the USD Index would result is roughly 0.3 per cent increase in inflation, roughly 0.7 per cent increase in unemployment, and roughly 0.2 per cent decrease in the GDP growth rate.
Of course, all of the above analysis relates to a one-off 1% drop in the Dixie. One could extrapolate and suggest that a larger and sustained drop in the Dixie would be likely to aplify the expected stagnation in the Australian economy. This result is topical given the current pressures on the US dollar, especially through the introduction of a new BRICS currency. The question for government, and especially those in charge of fiscal and monetary policies, is this: What can Australia do today to mitigate the envisaged possibility of stagflation?
